unnormalised: Planning a trip to India can be super exciting, but figuring out the addresses for all your bookings can be a bit of a headache, no? You've got your train tickets, your flight confirmations, and of course, those hotel reservations. Each one comes with its own unique jumble of numbers and street names, and sometimes they don't exactly match up. I mean, who hasn't spent a frantic 10 minutes trying to decipher whether their hotel is actually at "14 B, Linking Road" or "No. 14/B, Linking Rd"? It's a common desi travel struggle, bhai!

It's a common desi travel struggle, bhai!

unnormalised: Let's talk hotels, because that's usually where the biggest confusion lies. You book a swanky room at "The Grand Imperial, 123 Main St, Delhi, 110001" but when you actually try to find it using Google Maps, you end up near some totally different place. Always double-check the pin, folks. Also, watch out for the abbreviations. "St." can mean Street, or sometimes even State, depending on who you ask. And what's with all the "Opp." (Opposite) or "Nr." (Near) stuff? It's like a treasure hunt sometimes!

Always double-check the pin, folks. Also, watch out for the abbreviations. "Street" can mean Street, or sometimes even State, depending on who you ask. And what's with all the "Opposite" (Opposite) or "Near" (Near) stuff? It's like a treasure hunt sometimes!

unnormalised: Then there's the whole business with postal codes. You'd think they'd be simple enough, right? Wrong! You get different formats depending on where you're booking from. Some Indian websites will give you the standard 6-digit PIN, like "400001" for Mumbai. But international sites might want something completely different, expecting maybe a hyphen or something weird. It's always good to have a backup.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on addresses in rural areas! Forget "Main St" or "Linking Rd". You're more likely to get something like "Village - Rampur, Post - Shivnagar, Dist - Varanasi, UP, 221001". Good luck explaining that to your cab driver. Pro-tip: Screenshot the directions or have someone write it in the local language.

unnormalised: But, honestly, a little bit of confusion is just part of the fun, isn't it? Embrace the chaos! Just make sure you have all your confirmation emails readily accessible, maybe a few screenshots saved on your phone, and definitely a power bank. Oh, and maybe a sense of humor. You're gonna need it when your auto-rickshaw driver insists that "Plot No. 7, Sector 18, Gurgaon, Haryana, 122015" is just "seedha, left, right," and then proceeds to take you on a scenic tour of the city.

"Kahaan hai?" is a phrase you might find yourself using a lot! Safe travels!
